choices.B: The document is a backup file if the system needs to be recovered.
choices.D: The document is a keylogger that stores all keystrokes should the account be compromised.
choices.C: The document is a standard file that the OS needs to verify the login credentials.
choices.A: The document is a honeyfile and is meant to attract the attention of a cyberintruder.

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST explains the reason why a server administrator would place a document named password.txt on the desktop of an administrator account on a server?

A security engineer at an offline government facility is concerned about the validity of an SSL certificate. The engineer wants to perform the fastest check with the least delay to determine if the certificate has been revoked. Which of the following would BEST meet these requirements?

OCSP (Online Certificate Status Protocol) is one of two common schemes for maintaining the security of a server and other network resources. The other, older method, which OCSP has superseded in some scenarios, is known as Certificate Revocation List (CRL).

In cryptography, a certificate revocation list (or CRL) is "a list of digital certificates that have been revoked by the issuing certificate authority (CA) before their scheduled expiration date and should no longer be trusted". Might be C if it is spelled crL

This must be typo - CRL
 Keyword: offline government facility - how can OCSP used for offiline facility

I know C says CRI but this is most likely a typo from whoever typed up this question here. If on the real exam the answer CRL is among choices you should know that CRL is faster than OCSP.

Source: https://docs.microfocus.com/NNMi/10.30/Content/Administer/NNMi_Deployment/Advanced_Configurations/Cert_Validation_CRL_and_OCSP.htm

I think we must assume this offline facility is using an internal PKI? If that is the case, then yeah, OCSP is the answer. A more obvious choice would be OCSP stapling. A CRL for an internal structure wouldn't be very big though.
I think the answer is B because C says CRI not CRL. Either it's a type or another reading comprehension question lol

comments.content: The question asks: "the fastest check with the least delay". OCSP can check in realtime if the certificate is valid. CRL must be scheduled and downloaded locally, depending on the script, could also be updated every 24 hours.
Cause C is CRI, not CRL

questions.question_text: A company needs to fix some audit findings related to its physical security. A key finding was that multiple people could physically enter a location at the same time. Which of the following is the BEST control to address this audit finding?

questions.question_text:
A network administrator was concerned during an audit that users were able to use the same passwords the day after a password change policy took effect. The following settings are in place:
✑ Users must change their passwords every 30 days.
Users cannot reuse the last 10 passwords.
//IMG//

Which of the following settings would prevent users from being able to immediately reuse the same passwords?

choices.A: Minimum password age of five days
choices.C: Password length greater than ten characters

discussion.content: Minimum Password Age is normally used in conjunction with a setting to prevent re-use of X number of previous passwords - the minimum password age is intended to discourage users from cycling through their previous passwords to get back to a preferred one. Provided answer is correct.

Set Enforce password history to 24. This will help mitigate vulnerabilities that are caused by password reuse.
Set Maximum password age to expire passwords between 60 and 90 days. Try to expire the passwords between major business cycles to prevent work loss.
Configure Minimum password age so that you do not allow passwords to be changed immediately.

The last key word of the question
How to stop users not to ruse the same password
So change password history

Key word the same password means password reusability or using the same password over agun and again this is risky business. So If increasing password history to 10 limits no user can reuse the last 10 paswords
The “Enforce password history” setting in Active Directory is used to determine the number of unique passwords a user must use before they can use an old password again. This is an important setting because password reuse is a common issue – the more often the same (or similar) password is used, the greater chance that the password will be compromised in some way, such as in a brute force attack, or even via shoulder surfing
-The Minimum password age policy setting determines the period of time (in days) that a password must be used before the user can change it. You can set a value between 1 and 998 days.
They must use password for at least five days before they can change it
Huh? Someone explain this one to me please. Actually forget that I'm just skipping it...
The Minimum password age policy setting determines the period of time (in days) that a password must be used before the user can change it
